head.title: A Ceramic Renaissance For a Town That Potters Made

hedline.hl1: A Ceramic Renaissance For a Town That Potters Made

abstract.p: Comment on ceramics produced in St-Quentin la Poterie, France, by Charles Essautier (Currents); photo (S)

block.p: The town of St.-Quentin la Poterie gets its name from the potters, as many as 80 in the 1800's, who set up factories there because of the excellent local clay. When plastic arrived, that industry disappeared -- until Charles Eissautier opened shop in 1983, bringing artisanal pottery back to St.-Quentin. Modern and traditional crockery, decorative objects, outdoor planters, glazed and unglazed, every piece is handmade. The planters are frost-resistant and will not crack in cold winters. Prices go from $7 for a pot 4 1/2 inches high to $215 for a 17 1/2-inch pot like the one above, plus shipping: www.Raison-de-Plus.fr or (011) 33-4-66-22-58-70, La Poterie Eissautier, 371, route d'Uzes, St.-Quentin la Poterie.
